neighbors.name: Justin K. Shepler
neighbors.claims: Justin K. Shepler is the listed resident and owner of the property at 4204 N 126th St in Wyandotte County (PIN 209904) ([Realtor](https://www.realtor.com/propertyrecord-search/66109/N-126th-St)). Public record searches reveal no evidence of him holding elected office, board seats, or engaging in advocacy regarding local development or renewable energy projects as of February 2026 ([Wyandotte Daily](https://wyandotteonline.com)).
neighbors.influence_justification: No public roles or advocacy found

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach him one-on-one with a respectful, informative conversation, since he has no known affiliations. Listen to any personal concerns he raises about property impacts and address them directly.

neighbors.name: Morganne Appl-Culp & Tyler Culp; Cory & Stefanie Appl
neighbors.claims: Morganne M. Appl-Culp is an occupational therapist who received her Master of Occupational Therapy from Rockhurst University ([Rockhurst University](https://wyandotteonline.com/kck-residents-receive-degrees-from-rockhurst/)). Tyler Culp serves as the Vice President of Sales for Empower Brokerage ([Empower Brokerage](https://theorg.com/org/empower-brokerage/org-chart/tyler-culp)). Cory M. Appl serves as the Administrator and Treasurer for Spectrum Home Health and the Spectrum Health Foundation ([ProPublica](https://projects.propublica.org/nonprofits/organizations/481160123)). Cory M. Appl is a recipient of USDA agricultural subsidies for farming operations in Wyandotte County ([EWG](https://farm.ewg.org/top_recips.php?fips=20209&progcode=totalfarm&page=1)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Corporate leadership roles (VP Sales, Foundation Treasurer)

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage the family with a professional approach, acknowledging their roles in healthcare administration and business. Involve an agricultural liaison to discuss how the project will protect their farming interests, while being prepared to discuss economic benefits given their business backgrounds.

neighbors.name: Dylan M. Alexander & Cali D. Alexander
neighbors.claims: Dylan M. Alexander is employed as a Firefighter/EMT with the Kansas City, Kansas Fire Department (KCKFD) ([Kansas OpenGov](https://kansasopengov.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/county_ot_2020-2024.csv)). In May 2023, he was recognized by the VFW as the National & State Firefighter of the Year for heroic life-saving actions during a November 2022 apartment complex fire ([Wyandotte County UG](https://www.wycokck.org/Engage-With-Us/News-articles/2023-KCKFD-Awards-Ceremony)). Cali Alexander is a graduate of Fort Hays State University, having completed a Bachelor of General Studies in Human Services in 2018 ([FHSU News](https://www.fhsu.edu/news/2019/03/fort-hays-state-university-announces-fall-2018-graduates)). Family obituaries confirm the couple's marriage and long-standing ties to the region ([Amos Family Funeral Home](https://www.amosfamily.com/obituaries/kermalene-skahan)). No public statements regarding renewable energy development were found for either individual.
neighbors.influence_justification: Award-winning public servant (National Firefighter of the Year)

approach_recommendations.engage: Acknowledge Dylan's public service record. Approach via a trusted community liaison or fellow first responder. Focus on safety protocols, emergency access, and how the project supports local infrastructure/services relevant to public safety.

neighbors.profile_summary: Dylan Alexander is a highly decorated local firefighter, elevating his community standing. The household appears to be younger/active workforce. No evidence of anti-development sentiment.

neighbors.name: Terry H. Mertens & Charlotte L. Mertens
neighbors.claims: Terry and Charlotte Mertens are private residents of Wyandotte County. Family records identify Charlotte (née Bolander) as the wife of Terry Mertens and step-daughter of long-time area resident George Andervich ([Terrace Park Funeral Home](https://www.terraceparkfuneralhome.com/obituaries/george-andervich)). Comprehensive searches of Wyandotte County Planning Commission minutes and local news archives yield no record of the Mertens speaking publicly on zoning, development, or renewable energy matters ([Wyandotte County Planning Minutes](https://www.wycokck.org/files/assets/public/v/2/clerk/documents/agendas-amp-minutes/full-commission/2016-september-planning-zoning-full-commission-minutes.pdf)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Private residents; no identified civic leadership roles

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach as private landowners with deep family roots in the area. Focus on low-impact design, visual buffering to maintain privacy, and respect for the rural character of their property.

neighbors.profile_summary: Private landowners with extended family history in the region. No digital footprint suggests active opposition, but family legacy implies potential sensitivity to land use changes.

neighbors.claims: Jason Huston is a Project Manager for Stevenson Company, Inc., a stainless steel manufacturing firm in the region ([Stevenson Company News](https://stevensoncompanyinc.com/news/jason-huston-named-project-manager-for-growing-clientele)). Corporate biographies confirm he resides in the Kansas City area with his wife, Becky ([Stevenson Company Staff](https://www.stevensoncompanyinc.com/contact/staff-bios)). No evidence was found of Tanney or Huston voicing opinions on local development or renewable energy in news or public records, nor do they appear in local planning commission minutes ([Wyandotte County Planning Minutes](https://www.wycokck.org/files/assets/public/v/2/clerk/documents/agendas-amp-minutes/full-commission/2016-may-planning-zoning-full-commission-minutes.pdf)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Private sector employee; no public office found

approach_recommendations.engage: Jason works in industrial project management/manufacturing; technical competence and professional project planning may appeal to him. Focus on the engineering integrity and low nuisance profile of the project.

neighbors.profile_summary: Professional household. Jason is a Project Manager in manufacturing/industrial sector. Likely amenable to logical, well-planned engineering discussions. No history of opposition.

Appl is a recipient of USDA agricultural subsidies in Wyandotte County ([EWG Farm Subsidies](https://farm.ewg.org/top_recips.php?fips=20209&progcode=totalfarm&page=1)) and served as a co-executor for the estate of Helen Ann Henderson in 2021 alongside John F. Sanders ([Wyandotte Echo](https://wyandotteecho.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/Echo062421A.pdf)). approach_recommendations.engage: Reach out through a trusted agricultural community contact to acknowledge the family’s farming legacy. Discuss how the project can accommodate farmland use, emphasizing respect for their land and livelihood given the mixed medical and agricultural background.

neighbors.name: Jessica and Evan Blomeyer
neighbors.claims: Jessica and Evan Blomeyer are residents of Kansas City, KS ([Way-Watson Funeral Home](https://www.waywatson.com/obituaries/helen-blomeyer)). Evan Blomeyer is the step-son of the late Helen Owens Blomeyer, a registered nurse and Army veteran ([Way-Watson Funeral Home](https://www.waywatson.com/obituaries/helen-blomeyer)). The Blomeyer surname appears in historical Kansas business records in connection with Stuart Hunter (Neighbor N-03) through the professional association "Blomeyer & Hunter, Chartered," registered in Kansas City, KS in 1984, suggesting a potential multi-generational or professional link between these neighbors ([Kansas Register](https://sos.ks.gov/publications/register/1984/Vol_3_No_27_July_5_1984_p_901-924.pdf)). No specific public records were found regarding their stance on renewable energy development.
neighbors.influence_justification: Private residents; no current public office found

approach_recommendations.engage: Reach out with a neighborly approach, emphasizing that the project will respect their property values and quiet lifestyle. Note potential familial or professional connection to Neighbor N-03 (Stuart Hunter).

neighbors.name: Robert K. and Donna L. Creten
neighbors.claims: Robert and Donna Creten are associated with a long-established farming family in the region; "Creten Farms" has been a registered entity in the area since 1966 ([Manta](https://www.manta.com/c/mm7p7vp/creten-farms)). The Creten family has a documented history of challenging county land-use decisions; in the case *Creten v. Board of County Commissioners* (1970), the family litigated a denial of a special use permit for a mobile home park, demonstrating a willingness to engage legally regarding property rights and zoning ([Justia](https://law.justia.com/cases/kansas/supreme-court/1986/57-559-1.html)). No specific record was found of the current owners speaking out on renewable energy issues in recent local news.
neighbors.influence_justification: Longtime farming family with history of land-use litigation

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage via a respected agricultural peer. Be aware of the family's history of land-use litigation (*Creten v. Bd. of County Comm'rs*); emphasize fair contracting and respect for property rights.

neighbors.name: Stuart Hunter
neighbors.claims: Stuart Hunter is a Wyandotte County landowner who shares a historical professional link with the Blomeyer family (Neighbor N-01). State records from 1984 list a professional association titled "Blomeyer & Hunter, Chartered" in Kansas City, KS, indicating a likely background in law or professional services ([Kansas Register](https://sos.ks.gov/publications/register/1984/Vol_3_No_27_July_5_1984_p_901-924.pdf)). Despite this historical professional footprint, he does not appear in recent local media reports or public records regarding community discussions on land use or development.
neighbors.influence_justification: Historical professional status (Chartered association); linked to N-01

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach with professional courtesy suitable for a likely retired professional. Leverage the connection to the Blomeyer family (N-01) if appropriate.

neighbors.name: Guy B. Tiner
neighbors.claims: Guy B. Tiner is a longtime resident of Bonner Springs and a veteran local developer [Bonner Springs City Council](https://www.bonnersprings.org/Archive.aspx?ADID=230). He operates **Tiner Construction** and has been involved in residential developments such as "The Villages at Deerfield" and "Lei Valley" [Bonner Springs Planning Commission](https://www.bonnersprings.org/Archive.aspx?ADID=414). He is the registered agent for **LER Properties II LLC**, which holds land interests in the county [Wyandotte Echo](https://wyandotteecho.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/10/Echo100721A.pdf). In public hearings, he has self-identified as a "baby boomer" and noted his service on a regional committee guiding Kansas City's World Cup hosting activities [Wyandotte County UGTV](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Uq185bchZSs).
neighbors.influence_justification: Active developer; served on regional World Cup committee

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage regarding his development experience and regional committee work. Acknowledge his role in local housing projects like Lei Valley to build professional rapport.

neighbors.name: SP Bennet Lake Development, LLC
neighbors.claims: SP Bennet Lake Development, LLC is a special-purpose entity associated with Scannell Properties, a national real estate development firm based in Indianapolis ([leinumber.com](https://www.leinumber.com/leicert/2549006A3TMOUDEKUK90/)). The entity is developing the Scannell 435 Logistics Center, a 400-acre master-planned logistics park at 9822 Leavenworth Road in Wyandotte County, Kansas City, KS ([loopnet.com](https://www.loopnet.com/Listing/9700-Leavenworth-Rd-Kansas-City-KS/30042694/)) ([ttnews.com](https://www.ttnews.com/articles/kansas-marvin-logistics-hub)). Earthwork for the project began circa late 2023 to early 2024, securing Marvin Lumber and Cedar Company as an anchor tenant for a 400,000 sq. ft. manufacturing facility ([windowanddoor.com](https://www.windowanddoor.com/news/marvin-selects-kansas-city-new-manufacturing-facility)). Scannell Properties has a documented history of integrating renewable energy into its industrial developments, including installing extensive solar arrays and battery energy storage systems at other logistics facilities ([arconational.com](https://www.arconational.com/arco-partners-with-scannell-properties-on-manufacturing-facility-for-plant-prefab/)) ([energy.gov](https://www.energy.gov/sites/prod/files/2019/06/f63/101482.pdf)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Controls a major 400-acre industrial development (Scannell 435 Logistics Center); backed by national developer Scannell Properties; secured high-profile tenant (Marvin) with state government backing.

approach_recommendations.engage: Coordinate with Scannell Properties’ project leads regarding the 435 Logistics Center timeline. Highlight Helpen’s ability to provide complementary renewable energy infrastructure, referencing Scannell's past inclusion of solar arrays and battery storage in their industrial projects.

neighbors.profile_summary: SP Bennet Lake Development, LLC is the local holding entity for Scannell Properties' major industrial project, the Scannell 435 Logistics Center. They are actively developing the site for high-value tenants like Marvin Windows. The parent company, Scannell Properties, has a demonstrated track record of supporting and integrating solar and battery storage into their logistics parks.

neighbors.name: Marvin Lumber and Cedar Company, LLC
neighbors.claims: Marvin Lumber and Cedar Company, LLC (Marvin) is a family-owned window and door manufacturing firm founded in 1912 and based in Warroad, Minnesota ([pestel-analysis.com](https://pestel-analysis.com/blogs/brief-history/marvin)). In 2024, Marvin began earthwork on a 400,000 sq. ft. production facility in the Scannell 435 Logistics Center in Kansas City, KS, representing a capital investment of approximately $76.5 million ([kansascommerce.gov](https://www.kansascommerce.gov/2024/03/marvin-investing-76-5m-creating-600-jobs-in-kansas-city-kansas/)). The project is actively supported by Governor Laura Kelly and local officials, who cited the creation of 100 initial jobs and up to 600 jobs by 2028 ([ingrams.com](https://ingrams.com/article/window-door-manufacturer-selects-kck-for-76m-facility-600-new-jobs/)). Marvin has a corporate commitment to sustainability, with manufacturing operations that incorporate renewable energy sources and environmental standards ([mags.constructioninfocus.com](https://mags.constructioninfocus.com/mag/_Backups/CIFDec2024-old11/flipbook.pdf)). The company chose Wyandotte County after a multi-state search due to the region's workforce and collaborative economic development approach ([woodworkingnetwork.com](https://www.woodworkingnetwork.com/management/fdmc-300/marvin-selects-site-new-76-million-manufacturing-facility)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Major new regional employer (600 planned jobs); secured $76.5M+ investment; heavily backed by Governor Kelly and Wyandotte County Economic Development Council.

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage Marvin's Kansas City operations director regarding shared sustainability goals. Highlight how Helpen's development aligns with Marvin's corporate commitment to renewable energy sources and environmental manufacturing standards.

neighbors.profile_summary: Marvin is a significant new industrial stakeholder in Wyandotte County, currently constructing a major manufacturing hub. They have strong political capital via state incentives and job creation promises. Their corporate stance actively supports sustainable operations and renewable energy integration, making them a likely ally for responsible development.

neighbors.name: Scannell Properties #459, LLC
neighbors.claims: Scannell Properties #459, LLC is a special-purpose entity of Indianapolis-based Scannell Properties, a private real estate developer with over 300 projects across 44 U.S. states [Mid-America Contractors](https://midamericacontractors.com/planning-has-started-for-the-woodlands-racetrack-property/). In 2020, this LLC acquired the former Woodlands racetrack site in Kansas City, KS and constructed an Amazon distribution facility as the first phase of redevelopment [MetroWire Media](https://www.metrowiremedia.com/news/scannell-properties-targets-kc-as-prime-industrial-market). The property, now called I-435 Logistics Park, encompasses roughly 381 acres on which Scannell plans to build six industrial warehouse buildings totaling about 3.55 million square feet [MetroWire Media](https://www.metrowiremedia.com/news/scannell-properties-targets-kc-as-prime-industrial-market).
neighbors.influence_justification: National development firm with major local landholding and capital (381-acre project; Amazon as tenant)

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage the company’s local development director (e.g. Cameron Duff) to explore coordination; emphasize how the new project can complement their logistics park and address any operational concerns (traffic, infrastructure) to prevent opposition

neighbors.name: Unified Government Wy Co/KCK
neighbors.claims: The Unified Government of Wyandotte County/Kansas City, KS (UG) is the consolidated city-county government, which often holds title to land via its land bank or public projects and oversees all zoning and development approvals [RealtyHop](https://www.realtyhop.com/property-records/search/unified-government-of-wyandotte-county-k). UG officials supported Scannell Properties’ plan to redevelop the long-vacant Woodlands racetrack site, citing the creation of 1,000 new jobs and dedicating 70 acres of the area for public green space and trails as part of the project [Mid-America Contractors](https://midamericacontractors.com/planning-has-started-for-the-woodlands-racetrack-property/). In 2020, the UG Commission approved an industrial park proposal of over 3 million square feet of warehouse space on that site as a key economic development initiative for the county [Mid-America Contractors](https://midamericacontractors.com/planning-has-started-for-the-woodlands-racetrack-property/).
neighbors.influence_justification: Local government authority; controls zoning, incentives, and holds adjacent land; central to approval process

approach_recommendations.engage: Coordinate early with UG’s economic development officials and county commissioners; frame the project as aligned with community benefits (employment, tax base) and ensure compliance with local plans to secure their support

neighbors.name: Anita Andrews Revocable Trust
neighbors.claims: See RESIDENT table.
neighbors.influence_justification: Private individual landowner with no known public or economic influence

overview_summary: Of the 28 neighbors profiled, 23 are private residents and five are organizations, with two entities currently expressing support and 26 remaining unknown. The four high-influence and six medium-influence stakeholders include the Unified Government of Wyandotte County/KCK and industrial entities like Scannell Properties and Marvin, whose existing large-scale manufacturing and logistics projects align with regional growth. While no opposition has been documented, the high number of low-influence residents and long-time farming families suggests a need for personalized engagement to address localized concerns.
